clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of External Nasal Nerve Block in Prevention of Postoperative Agitation Following Nasal Surgeries
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of External Nasal Nerve Block on Postoperative Agitation Following Nasal Surgeries Under General Anesthesia. Randomized, Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Emergence agitation following general anaesthesia may lead to serious complications like self-extubation or removal of catheters, which can lead to hypoxia, aspiration pneumonia, bleeding or reoperation. Nose surgery is associated with a higher incidence of emergence agitation. The investigators planned to evaluate the efficacy of external nasal nerve block in prevention of postoperative agitation following external nasal surgeries under general anesthesia(GA).

primary_outcome.time_frame: Emergence is defined as the time interval from discontinuation of anesthesia to 5 min after extubation.
primary_outcome.description: Assessment done using Richmond agitation- sedation scale (RASS)

secondary_outcome.description: Fentanyl boluses were given in response to changes in hemodynamics (more than 15% increases in MAP and HR than the baseline values taken after induction by 5 minutes)

clinical_study.condition: Agitation States as Acute Reaction to Gross Stress

arm_group.description: patients allocated for external nasal nerve block with saline adrenaline 1/200,000 (placebo)
'External nasal nerve block by Xylocaine, adrenaline'

intervention.description: Three single (midline injection) and 4 paired (bilateral injection) sites to block the external nasal sensation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 110 adult patients of ASA physical status I and II,
- Age 20-60 years,
- Scheduled for elective external nasal surgeries in which nasal packing on each side was used postoperatively for 24 hours.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. History of uncontrolled hypertension,
2. Ischemic or valvular heart disease,
3. Use of MAO inhibitors or adrenergic blocking drugs,
4. Cognitive impairment,
5. Patients taking antipsychotics,
6. Renal insufficiency or liver dysfunction
